sutras.commentary: This sutra marks the beginning of the formal instruction in yoga.

sutras.translation: Yoga is the cessation of the modifications of the mind
sutras.commentary: The most famous definition of yoga. Citta = mind-stuff, Vritti = modifications/fluctuations, Nirodha = cessation/restraint.

sutras.translation: Then the seer abides in their own true nature
sutras.commentary: When the mind is still, consciousness rests in its pure state.

sutras.translation: At other times, the seer identifies with the modifications
sutras.commentary: When the mind is active, we mistake mental fluctuations for our true self.

sutras.translation: The modifications are five-fold, and are either afflicted or non-afflicted
sutras.commentary: Five types of mental modifications exist, some causing suffering, others not.

sutras.translation: Austerity, self-study, and surrender to the divine constitute the yoga of action
sutras.commentary: The three components of Kriya Yoga for practical spiritual development.

sutras.sanskrit: यम नियमासन प्राणायाम प्रत्याहार धारणा ध्यान समाधयोऽष्टावङ्गानि
sutras.translation: The eight limbs are: restraints, observances, posture, breath control, sense withdrawal, concentration, meditation, and absorption
sutras.commentary: The famous Ashtanga (8-limbed) path of yoga.

sutras.translation: Concentration is binding consciousness to a single point
sutras.commentary: The practice of dharana - sustained focus on one object.

sutras.translation: Meditation is the continuous flow of awareness on that point
sutras.commentary: Dhyana is when concentration becomes effortless and continuous.

sutras.translation: Samadhi is when consciousness becomes absorbed in the object, losing self-awareness
sutras.commentary: The highest state where subject and object merge.

sutras.translation: Siddhis (powers) are attained by birth, herbs, mantras, austerities, or samadhi
sutras.commentary: Five ways spiritual powers can manifest.
